Bullseye Blues Records | associated_acts = The Rockets
[[Sam Myers]]
[[The Fabulous Thunderbirds]] | website = [http://www.ansonandtherockets.com Ansonandtherockets.com] | notable_instruments = }} '''Anson Funderburgh''' (born '''James Anson Funderburgh''', November 14, 1954,{{cite web|url=http://www.familytreelegends.com/records/txbirths?c=search&first=Anson&last=Funderburgh&spelling=Exact&11_year=&11_month=0&11_day=0&4=&14=&SubmitSearch.x=0&SubmitSearch.y=0&SubmitSearch=Submit |title=Texas Births, 1926-1995 |publisher=Familytreelegends.com |date= |accessdate=2013-03-25}}{{cite web|url=http://www.veromi.net/Summary.asp?fn=James&mn=Anson&ln=Funderburgh&dobmm=11&dobdd=14&doby=1954&city=&state=&age=&vw=&Search=&Input=&x=0&y=0 |title=People Summary |publisher=Veromi.net |date=1954-11-14 |accessdate=2013-03-25}} [[Plano, Texas|Plano]], [[Texas]], [[United States]]){{cite web|last=Skelly |first=Richard |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/anson-funderburgh-mn0000588890 |title=Anson Funderburgh - Music Biography, Credits and Discography |publisher=AllMusic |date=1954-11-15 |accessdate=2013-03-25}} is an [[United States|American]] [[blues]] [[guitar]] player and [[bandleader]] of '''Anson Funderburgh and the Rockets''' since 1978.{{cite book | first= Tony | last= Russell | year= 1997 | title= The Blues - From [[Robert Johnson (musician)|Robert Johnson]] to [[Robert Cray]] | edition= | publisher=Carlton Books Limited | location= Dubai | page= 113 | isbn= 1-85868-255-X}} Their style incorporates both [[Chicago blues]] and [[Texas blues]]. ==Career== In 1981, Funderburgh released the Rockets' debut album ''Talk to You By Hand'' from [[New Orleans, Louisiana]] based [[Black Top Records]]. The band consisted of Anson, with [[Darrell Nulisch]] on vocals and [[harmonica]]. The album included a [[cover version]] of [[Earl King]]'s [[song]], "[[Come On (Earl King song)|Come On]]". ''Talk to You By Hand'' was also the first ever release by the [[record label]]. The band appeared at the 1984 [[San Francisco Blues Festival]]. When Nulisch left the band in 1985, Funderburgh invited the blues harmonica player [[Sam Myers]] from [[Jackson, Mississippi]] to fill in the spot. He stayed with the band until his death on July 17, 2006, appearing on eight albums with them. The first Rockets' [[sound recording and reproduction|recording]] featuring Myers was ''My Love Is Here To Stay'' which came out in 1986. Anson Funderburgh and the Rockets appeared in the 1994 film "China Moon," starring Ed Harris and Madeleine Stowe. They are shown playing "Tell Me What I Want To Hear" from the self-titled release. As well as the [[recording studio|studio]] recordings, in 1990 the band played the [[Long Beach Blues Festival]]. The same year, they appeared on show number 109 of the [[NBC]] [[television program]], ''[[Sunday Night (American TV program)|Sunday Night]]''. In 1989 and 1990 the band's [[bassist]] was [[Mike Judge]], future [[animator]] and creator of ''[[Beavis and Butt-head]]'' and ''[[King of the Hill]]''.{{cite web|author=Posted by Bman |url=http://www.bmansbluesreport.com/2011/12/what-does-anson-funderburgh-have-to-do.html |title=Bman's Blues Report: What does Anson Funderburgh have to do with Beavis and Butt-Head |publisher=Bmansbluesreport.com |date=2011-12-07 |accessdate=2011-12-31}} Their song "Can We Get Together" was also featured in the film, ''[[21 Grams]]'' in 2003. In 2007, Funderburgh played on and produced [[John Németh]]'s album, ''Magic Touch''.{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/magic-touch-mw0000569312/credits |title=Magic Touch - John Nemeth : Credits |publisher=AllMusic |date=2007-01-30 |accessdate=2013-03-25}} Németh had briefly replaced Myers in Funderburgh's backing band.{{cite web|last=Leggett |first=Steve |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/john-nemeth-mn0000484219 |title=John Nemeth - Music Biography, Credits and Discography |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2013-03-25}} In 2011, ''The Mill Block Blues'' album was released. The CD is unique in that a portion of the sales of the album will be donated to help fellow musicians in need via the HART Fund. The HART Fund (Handy Artist Relief Trust) is a service provided by the Blues Foundation which provides for acute, chronic and preventive medical and dental care as well as funeral expenses for blues musicians.{{cite web|url=http://www.ruffkuttblues.com/ |title=Ruff Kutt Blues |publisher=Ruff Kutt Blues |date= |accessdate=2011-12-31}}{{cite web|author=Posted by Bman |url=http://www.bmansbluesreport.com/2011/11/new-release-mill-block-blues-ruff-kutt.html |title=Bman's Blues Report: New Release: Mill Block Blues - Ruff Kutt - Review |publisher=Bmansbluesreport.com |date=2011-11-14 |accessdate=2011-12-31}} In 2013, Funderburgh produced and featured on the Andy T. - Nick Nixon band's ''Drink Drank Drunk'', released on [[Delta Groove Productions|Delta Groove]].{{cite web|url=http://www.deltagrooveproductions.com/music/releases/drinkdrankdrunk/main.html|title=Andy T - Nick Nixon Band 'Drink Drank Drunk'|publisher=Delta Groove Productions}} In 2014, he was nominated for a [[Blues Music Award]] in the 'Best Instrumentalist – Guitar' category.{{cite web|url=http://blues.about.com/od/bluesawards/a/2014-Blues-Music-Awards.htm |title=2014 Blues Music Awards Nominees and Winners |publisher=Blues.about.com |date= |accessdate=2014-05-16}} ==Discography== *1981: ''Talk to You By Hand'' (Black Top) *1985: ''She Knocks Me Out!'' (Black Top) *1986: ''My Love Is Here To Stay'' (Black Top) *1987: ''Sins'' (Black Top) *1990: ''Rack 'Em Up'' (Black Top) *1991: ''Tell Me What I Want to Hear'' (Black Top) *1995: ''Live At the Grand Emporium'' (Black Top) *1997: ''That's What They Want'' (Black Top) *1999: ''Change In My Pocket'' (Bullseye Blues) *2003: ''Which Way Is Texas?'' (Bullseye Blues) *2011: ''Mill Block Blues'' (Ruff Kutt) *2013: ''Deal With It'' (EllerSoul Records) *2013: ''Drink Drank Drunk'' (Produced, featured) (Delta Groove) ==See also== *[[List of blues musicians]] *[[Black Top Records catalog]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.ansonandtherockets.com Anson Funderburgh's web site] *{{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p78253|label=Anson Funderburgh}} {{Authority control|VIAF=3910164}} {{Persondata | NAME =Funderburgh, Anson | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION =[[United States|American]] blues guitarist and bandleader | DATE OF BIRTH =November 14, 1954 | PLACE OF BIRTH =[[Plano, Texas]], [[United States]] | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Funderburgh, Anson}} [[Category:1954 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American blues guitarists]] [[Category:American blues musicians]] [[Category:People from Plano, Texas]] [[Category:Musicians from Texas]] [[Category:Texas blues musicians]] [[Category:Chicago blues musicians]] [[Category:Black Top Records artists]] [[Category:Contemporary blues musicians]]
